lead_paragraph: Twitter has relied on stock-based compensation more than its peers in Silicon Valley, and that has unavoidable implications for potential buyers.

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

headline.print_headline: Stock Grants Add to Twitter Cost
headline.main: Twitter’s Steep Premium: The Cost of Employee Stock Grants

snippet: Twitter has relied on stock-based compensation more than its peers in Silicon Valley, and that has unavoidable implications for potential buyers....
abstract: Stock analysts determine Twitter is overvalued because it pays out so much stock to its employees, roughly 31 cents in stock-based compensation for every dollar of sales it collects, based on 2015 figures; say potential buyers need to consider these costs before making bids.
